Sorry to hear about the theft Darcy.

I hope it returns safely.

-Thom

From: <samurai@...>

Sent: Friday, January 21, 2005 11:12 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert


>

> A Tokubetsu Juyo Yukimitsu was stolen in transit from me to Japan.

> Last year a Juyo Token Niji Kunitoshi was taken in the same manner, it
> was scanned by someone as being sent to Canada Customs, then it
> vanished. There was a several week period in both cases of me having to
> fight people who's computer screens told them something that wasn't
> true, then finally they admitted the package vanished into thin air.
>
> Last year they searched the warehouse several times without it turning
> up, and when I said I was sending the police over, 15 minutes later the
> sword appeared in some office where someone had "mistakenly left it"
> after scanning that it was sent to customs.
>
> My hope is that the same scam is being played again.
>
> Obviously with the cost of a blade like this, it is not a trivial matter
> and I feel kind of sick. Insurance says they will not cover it.
>
> Pictures of the blade are on my site as I have the paperwork.
>
> It has gone missing or been stolen in the Toronto area. Lately there
> has been a new study group formed in Toronto with a lot of attendees. It

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert
messages.msgSnippet: Doug, Those senior members of the group are my friends. If you ve read what I wrote as blaming the group, you got it completely wrong, and that would be an
messages.messageBody:
Doug,

Those senior members of the group are my friends.

If you've read what I wrote as blaming the group, you got it completely
wrong, and that would be an inappropriate conclusion on your own part.

Please don't turn this into a pissy flame war because honestly this is
not a good situation and I'm just asking people to be on the lookout.

For what I'm saying, it's just that as information percolates and
disseminates from meeting attendees to friends, to possibly sketchy
friends, it is not clear what the long term effects are so that those of
us who are used to sword value being completely under the radar have to
start being a bit more alert.

Six degrees of separation are between every person in North America.

This means that chances are extremely good that some friend of a friend
of a friend is a thief.

This is what I'm indicating.

- darcy

<dblain@...> writes:

> As a member of this new study group, I take exception to your
> statement that this group may be responsible in any way for an
> increase in sword related crimes. Clearly you have major issues with
> the courier you are using and the police should be involved
> immediately upon any suspicious activity, but please do not besmirch
> the efforts of the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre as it attempts to
> educate people on the samurai sword. Senior members of the JSS/US are
> active participants in this group and I am sure they are not going to
> be a party to any activity that does not promote a complete respect
> for the sword and its history. Sorry to vent, but this was not an
> appropriate conclusion on your part.
> ____________________________________________ Doug Blain, Manager,
> Information Technology Security Computing & Communications Services,
> University of Guelph Phone: (519) 824-4120 ext. 56475 Fax: (519)
> 767-1620

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: samurai@...
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Friday, January 21, 2005 11:12 AM
> Subject: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert



> A Tokubetsu Juyo Yukimitsu was stolen in transit from me to Japan.

> Last year a Juyo Token Niji Kunitoshi was taken in the same manner, it
> was scanned by someone as being sent to Canada Customs, then it
> vanished. There was a several week period in both cases of me having to
> fight people who's computer screens told them something that wasn't
> true, then finally they admitted the package vanished into thin air.

> Last year they searched the warehouse several times without it turning
> up, and when I said I was sending the police over, 15 minutes later the
> sword appeared in some office where someone had "mistakenly left it"
> after scanning that it was sent to customs.

> My hope is that the same scam is being played again.

> Obviously with the cost of a blade like this, it is not a trivial matter
> and I feel kind of sick. Insurance says they will not cover it.

> Pictures of the blade are on my site as I have the paperwork.

> It has gone missing or been stolen in the Toronto area. Lately there
> has been a new study group formed in Toronto with a lot of attendees. It
> is possible with the new dissemination of information there that there
> is more knowledge about the value of these swords and so we're going to
> start seeing more thefts.

> Here's the link to my site:

> http://www.nihonto.ca/yukimitsu-2/

> Please, everyone be on the lookout for someone who is asking questions
> about an antique sword that they have found, and are trying to get the
> value of that matches the pictures and description on my site. If
> someone presents it to you in person, please take it and call the police
> immediately.

> - darcy

For what I'm saying, it's just that as information percolates and

Six degrees of separation are between every person in North America.

of a friend is a thief.

This is what I'm indicating.

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert
messages.msgSnippet:
I can appreciate the response to the writers original posting, however,  I
do NOT believe that the writers intent of the posting was to directly link
the most
messages.messageBody:
I can appreciate the response to the writers original posting, however, I
do NOT believe that the writers intent of the posting was to directly link
the most recent JCCC efforts in sharing Japanese sword appreciation
information in the Toronto area with any sword theft activity - recent or
future - however is most likely directed and intended as an alert to anyone
who "may show an interest "of this particular stolen sword details to the
knowledgeable" people of this newly formed sword group and others
(particularly in Canada).

Rick Corbin
Calgary, Alberta
Canada
Nihonto@...


-------Original Message-------

From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Date: 01/21/05 09:37:39
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert

As a member of this new study group, I take exception to your statement that
this group may be responsible in any way for an increase in sword related
crimes. Clearly you have major issues with the courier you are using and the
police should be involved immediately upon any suspicious activity, but
please do not besmirch the efforts of the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre
as it attempts to educate people on the samurai sword. Senior members of the
JSS/US are active participants in this group and I am sure they are not
going to be a party to any activity that does not promote a complete respect
for the sword and its history. Sorry to vent, but this was not an
appropriate conclusion on your part.
____________________________________________
Doug Blain, Manager, Information Technology Security
Computing & Communications Services,
University of Guelph
Phone: (519) 824-4120 ext. 56475
Fax: (519) 767-1620

----- Original Message -----
From: samurai@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, January 21, 2005 11:12 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert



A Tokubetsu Juyo Yukimitsu was stolen in transit from me to Japan.

Last year a Juyo Token Niji Kunitoshi was taken in the same manner, it
was scanned by someone as being sent to Canada Customs, then it
vanished. There was a several week period in both cases of me having to
fight people who's computer screens told them something that wasn't
true, then finally they admitted the package vanished into thin air.

Last year they searched the warehouse several times without it turning
up, and when I said I was sending the police over, 15 minutes later the
sword appeared in some office where someone had "mistakenly left it"
after scanning that it was sent to customs.

My hope is that the same scam is being played again.

Obviously with the cost of a blade like this, it is not a trivial matter
and I feel kind of sick. Insurance says they will not cover it.

Pictures of the blade are on my site as I have the paperwork.

It has gone missing or been stolen in the Toronto area. Lately there
has been a new study group formed in Toronto with a lot of attendees. It
is possible with the new dissemination of information there that there
is more knowledge about the value of these swords and so we're going to
start seeing more thefts.

Here's the link to my site:

http://www.nihonto.ca/yukimitsu-2/

Please, everyone be on the lookout for someone who is asking questions
about an antique sword that they have found, and are trying to get the
value of that matches the pictures and description on my site. If
someone presents it to you in person, please take it and call the police
immediately.

- darcy




-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Yahoo! Groups Links

a.. To visit your group on the web, go to:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/

b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
nihontostudy-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

> Yahoo! Groups Links

> *Yahoo! Groups Links*

> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/
>
> * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> nihontostudy-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
> <mailto:nihontostudy-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscribe>
>
> * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of
> Service <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>.

>
I don't believe that there was any accusation directed towards the study
group or it's members in this thread. It seems a perfectly logical
conclusion that as knowledge of the intrinsic value of items is spread,
more interest will be directed towards those items from people of shady
character. This does not reflect upon the group disseminating the
knowledge, it's simply the darker side of human nature. It also does
not mean that one of the group is responsible (I could insert the pebble
thrown into the calm pond metaphor here... ).

I hope that the blade is recovered and that these incidents don't become
commonplace. I also hope that the discussion group meets with much success.

Buddy Ethridge
Director - Andonie Museum

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert
messages.msgSnippet: A fantastic sword, Darcy but a sickening story! Let s hope it turns up safe and sound!! Ron STL ... From: samurai@xhasc.com To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
messages.messageBody:
A fantastic sword, Darcy but a sickening story! Let's hope it turns up safe and sound!!

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: samurai@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, January 21, 2005 10:12 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert



A Tokubetsu Juyo Yukimitsu was stolen in transit from me to Japan.

Last year a Juyo Token Niji Kunitoshi was taken in the same manner, it
was scanned by someone as being sent to Canada Customs, then it
vanished. There was a several week period in both cases of me having to
fight people who's computer screens told them something that wasn't
true, then finally they admitted the package vanished into thin air.

Last year they searched the warehouse several times without it turning
up, and when I said I was sending the police over, 15 minutes later the
sword appeared in some office where someone had "mistakenly left it"
after scanning that it was sent to customs.

My hope is that the same scam is being played again.

Obviously with the cost of a blade like this, it is not a trivial matter
and I feel kind of sick. Insurance says they will not cover it.

Pictures of the blade are on my site as I have the paperwork.

It has gone missing or been stolen in the Toronto area. Lately there
has been a new study group formed in Toronto with a lot of attendees. It
is possible with the new dissemination of information there that there
is more knowledge about the value of these swords and so we're going to
start seeing more thefts.

Here's the link to my site:

http://www.nihonto.ca/yukimitsu-2/

Please, everyone be on the lookout for someone who is asking questions
about an antique sword that they have found, and are trying to get the
value of that matches the pictures and description on my site. If
someone presents it to you in person, please take it and call the police
immediately.

- darcy




------------------------------------------------------------------------------

b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:

As a member of this new study group, I take exception to your statement that this group may be responsible in any way for an increase in sword related crimes. Clearly you have major issues with the courier you are using and the police should be involved immediately upon any suspicious activity, but please do not besmirch the efforts of the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre as it attempts to educate people on the samurai sword. Senior members of the JSS/US are active participants in this group and I am sure they are not going to be a party to any activity that does not promote a complete respect for the sword and its history. Sorry to vent, but this was not an appropriate conclusion on your part.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert
messages.msgSnippet: Wow, that s a dozen Juyo, that is very frightening.  I have added that info to the Nihonto message board as well. The more eyes the better. Rich ... From: Jim
messages.messageBody:
Wow, that's a dozen Juyo, that is very frightening. I have added that info to the Nihonto message board as well. The more eyes the better.

Rich
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, April 24, 2003 10:38 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert


Please take a moment to look at the list below. Let me know off line if you have any questions or comments.

Thanks, Jim

---------------------------------------------------------------------

This letter I would really prefer not being urged to write to you, because it is not the type of letters I would like to receive as well!

So, please be prepared to read a really bad message:

On Friday 4th of April a theft occurred in Basle, Switzerland. All of the swords of Mr. Indlekofer, who died last October, were stolen, together with gold coins and jewels.

The swords were:

1.) Den Senjuin, Juyo (23)Tanto, 25 cm

2.) DenTaima Juyo (12) Katana, 69,30 cm

3.) Kinzogan Mei Taima Juyo (37) Katana, 66.60 cm

4.) Aritoshi, Juyo (36) Tachi, 78.70 cm

5.) Tegai, Juyo (35) Katana, 69.80 cm

6.) Hosho, Juyo (19) Katana 69.40 cm

7.) Den Shikkake, Juyo (17) Katana 70.90 cm

8.) Den Ryumon Nobuyoshi, Juyo (23) Katana, 70.60 cm (in Bizen style)

9.) Kinpunmei Ryumon Nobuyoshi, Juyo (11) Katana, 72.20 cm (in Yamato style)

10.) Omiya, Juyo (37) Katana, 69.60 cm

11.) Mitsumori (gakumei), Juyo (33) Wakizashi, 46,90 cm

12.) Kunimasa (Horikawa), Juyo (45) Katana, 70.55 cm

13.) Ushu Shonai Fujiwara Kiyondo, Ansei ni-nen, Efu ni-oite Kore-o tsukuru, 65,50 cm, Tokubetsu Hozon

14.) A Daisho (unknown makers)

It would be very kind of you if you could publish this in your next publication for your Society, if anybody gets hints of those swords, please information either to me or to the Kriminalkommissariat Basel-Stadt, Tel. Switzerland 061 267 71 71.

Many thanks in advance

Sincerely yours,

Michael Hagenbusch


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: stolen sword alert
messages.msgSnippet: Please take a moment to look at the list below.  Let me know off line if you have any questions or comments. Thanks,  Jim ... This letter I would really prefer
messages.messageBody:
Please take a moment to look at the list below. Let me know off line if you have any questions or comments.

Thanks, Jim

---------------------------------------------------------------------

This letter I would really prefer not being urged to write to you, because it is not the type of letters I would like to receive as well!

So, please be prepared to read a really bad message:

On Friday 4th of April a theft occurred in Basle, Switzerland. All of the swords of Mr. Indlekofer, who died last October, were stolen, together with gold coins and jewels.

The swords were:

1.) Den Senjuin, Juyo (23)Tanto, 25 cm

2.) DenTaima Juyo (12) Katana, 69,30 cm

3.) Kinzogan Mei Taima Juyo (37) Katana, 66.60 cm

4.) Aritoshi, Juyo (36) Tachi, 78.70 cm

5.) Tegai, Juyo (35) Katana, 69.80 cm

6.) Hosho, Juyo (19) Katana 69.40 cm

7.) Den Shikkake, Juyo (17) Katana 70.90 cm

8.) Den Ryumon Nobuyoshi, Juyo (23) Katana, 70.60 cm (in Bizen style)

9.) Kinpunmei Ryumon Nobuyoshi, Juyo (11) Katana, 72.20 cm (in Yamato style)

10.) Omiya, Juyo (37) Katana, 69.60 cm

11.) Mitsumori (gakumei), Juyo (33) Wakizashi, 46,90 cm

12.) Kunimasa (Horikawa), Juyo (45) Katana, 70.55 cm

13.) Ushu Shonai Fujiwara Kiyondo, Ansei ni-nen, Efu ni-oite Kore-o tsukuru, 65,50 cm, Tokubetsu Hozon

14.) A Daisho (unknown makers)

It would be very kind of you if you could publish this in your next publication for your Society, if anybody gets hints of those swords, please information either to me or to the Kriminalkommissariat Basel-Stadt, Tel. Switzerland 061 267 71 71.

Many thanks in advance

Sincerely yours,

Michael Hagenbusch
